update.description:
Partial and complete occlusion of the directional light from the line of sight of the camera should now cause the lens flare to diminish and disappear. If the center of the light is blocked, no lens flare will be visible

Along the way I also fixed manipulating lights in the 3D window. The bug is closely related to a problem that was causing lens flare occlusion ray cast checks to fail. 

![lens_flare_occlusion_lossy.gif](https://bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/798670463-lens_flare_occlusion_lossy.gif)
update.title: Support lens flare occlusion

content.raw:
ya that'll be useful. I added a new `LensFlare::SetScale` function and demonstrate it its use in the `LensFlareSensorPlugin` with a new `scale` SDF plugin param . Also updated test to include a camera with lens flare scale set to 0.1. a036072

Here's a screenshot showing a scale of 1.0 vs 0.1:

![lens_flare_scale.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/343518854-lens_flare_scale.png)

content.raw: I left a few minor comments, but I approve whether or not changes are made for those comments.
content.html: I left a few minor comments, but I approve whether or not changes are made for those comments.

content.raw:
I know there are already a lot of parentheses at play here, but I'd recommend putting (yet another) set of parentheses around `(flags & GZ_VISIBILITY_GUI)` and `(flags & GZ_VISIBILITY_SELECTABLE)` to make it explicit that those are effectively boolean expressions rather than logical conjunctions.

To make it simpler to read, it might be nice to break some of the logic out of the if-statement, like:

```
const bool guiOrSelectable = (flags & GZ_VISIBILITY_GUI) || (flags & GZ_VISIBILITY_SELECTABLE);
```

and then use `guiOrSelectable` in the if-statement.
content.html:
I know there are already a lot of parentheses at play here, but I'd recommend putting (yet another) set of parentheses around (flags & GZ_VISIBILITY_GUI) and (flags & GZ_VISIBILITY_SELECTABLE) to make it explicit that those are effectively boolean expressions rather than logical conjunctions.

To make it simpler to read, it might be nice to break some of the logic out of the if-statement, like:

const bool guiOrSelectable = (flags & GZ_VISIBILITY_GUI) || (flags & GZ_VISIBILITY_SELECTABLE);

and then use guiOrSelectable in the if-statement.

content.raw: Would it make sense to make this a parameter of the `LensFlare` class? I imagine there could be cases where a user wants the lens flare to be larger or smaller (e.g. maybe it's a cloudy day, so the lens flare should be smaller, or maybe we're on a space ship that's closer to the sun, so we want it to be larger).
content.html: Would it make sense to make this a parameter of the LensFlare class? I imagine there could be cases where a user wants the lens flare to be larger or smaller (e.g. maybe it's a cloudy day, so the lens flare should be smaller, or maybe we're on a space ship that's closer to the sun, so we want it to be larger).

content.raw: A `const CameraPtr &_camera` would also avoid incrementing the reference count, but that would be a micro-optimization.
content.html: A const CameraPtr &_camera would also avoid incrementing the reference count, but that would be a micro-optimization.
